data.title: OppFi: Collapsing Multiple, Exploding Profits - Something Doesn't Add Up
data.description:
In May last year, I had rated OppFi (OPFI) a Hold despite strong operating momentum. At the time, revenue growth was strong, charge-offs were improving, and margins were also expanding. But valuations were not compelling enough to compensate for the rising macro credit risks and uncertainties. I was concerned about the earnings durability in a potentially weakening consumer environment. I was also wary of a very competitive subprime lending segment and limited expansion potential. Since then, my wait for a better visibility of the credit cycle and a deeper valuation reset have both played out favorably to consider a Buy. All this while, operating strength remained intact.

Execution and Operating Strength

Interest and dividend income growth has strengthened from ~10% levels we were seeing in May last year. There is visible growth acceleration and further confirmation of a growth trend that had just emerged in Q1 2025. Q3 2025 also reported a ~41% YoY increase in adjusted net income. Guidance for revenue growth is solid (double digits) in Q4 and into 2026. Adjusted net income has also been guided significantly higher from $125-130m earlier to $137-$142m for the full year. That is a material revision for the full year with just a quarter left to report, although the YTD run rate was already pointing to ~$150m. This guidance upgrade could be interpreted as conservative expectation setting and upgraded with only better visibility and certainty – but even that better visibility and certainty counts.

Valuation Conducive

Since my May thesis, OppFi has corrected by ~24%, but valuations have contracted much more. With earnings revised upward, the forward P/E ratio, which was around 9x earlier, is now ~5x (far lower than the ~7x levels I had in mind to re-evaluate entries). At ~5x, markets are either discounting an earnings contraction phase ahead or are skeptical about earnings sustainability – OppFi's double-digit growth and repeated earnings guidance upgrades do not explain this sharp a multiple contraction. Even if earnings fall by ~30%, the P/E ratio expands to ~7-8x – levels I had found reasonable for a profitable specialty lender in 2025.

The price-to-book ratio is ~2.96x. This may look higher than traditional lenders who generally report valuations at around 1-2x the book value (median valuations ~1.2x). Specialty lending could be priced higher if the RoE and book value are expanding strongly. And in OppFi's case, both are visible. The book value dipped a bit before rising materially above the ~$30m mark seen in Q1 2025 (which was the basis of the May 2025 thesis). The RoE has also followed a similar expansion path and now sits at a very strong ~51% level. With ~$140m in projected earnings against $277m in equity, retained earnings should expand book value rapidly, compressing price-to-book valuations organically if profitability holds. Overall, at ~5x earnings and ~3x book with ~50% RoE, valuation now provides asymmetry – provided credit metrics remain within management’s targeted bands.

Credit - The Core Variable

Credit becomes the core variable for OppFi as it scales. While the macro-related credit risks I was wary of in May last year have not emerged, the macro uncertainty has not improved significantly either. The odds of a recession still loom, and credit deterioration cannot yet be ruled out – unless growth stabilizes, labor markets strengthen, and we have better clarity on monetary policy. However, we have lived through a tariff regime and its uncertainties without collapsing, and the odds of a recession, although still high, are decreasing.

Importantly, OppFi's credit quality is not showing any obvious signs of worsening. Net charge-offs are now 35% of revenue, only marginally higher than the 34% level seen last year. OppFi now has the capability to dynamically adjust pricing across risk bands, including adjustments at the weekly level. This means when losses rise, yields can adjust. Additionally, management has demonstrated a sustained strong recovery record for the past two years. Lower fixed costs also help cushion any rising loss scenario in a softer credit phase. OppFi's operating expenses fell to ~30% of revenue in Q3 2025, compared to 33% in the prior year. Interest expenses also fell to 6% of revenue (vs. 8% earlier).

The execution so far, overall, improves confidence in OppFi's ability to navigate a slightly deteriorating credit situation. And all is not well in terms of the credit environment – new vintages showing higher early payment defaults. Management has acknowledged a potentially worsening credit situation, but nothing that alters OppFi's ability to navigate it:

I'm not going to not say that credit isn't worse. It is worse than it was last year in the new segments, especially the new, but something that we can operate in now with our current pricing structure and how we operate.

The numbers so far do not show material impact overall. These are not the best credit conditions, but the impact appears to be controlled – offset by recoveries and cushioned by lower funding costs. The provisions data charted below (as a % of revenue) also shows controlled loss intensity relative to earnings power. In the past few quarters, the provision ratio has also stabilized within the 32-38% band, despite modest credit softening in newer vintages. Overall, credit costs are elevated but within a controllable band.

OppFi Is a Buy

Overall, I expect OppFi to continue its double-digit growth not only in the upcoming quarter but also in early 2026 as well. I think markets are cautious about OppFi now because of higher charge-offs in Q4, as indicated in the Q3 earnings call. I think that could be the case indeed (charge-offs drifting to the higher thirties), but that is not a structural issue or a reflection of macro worsening. Q4 may see higher charge-offs due to seasonal effects like seasoning and delinquency roll-forward mechanics and holiday spending stretching borrower liquidity. We have seen higher provisioning in Q4 2024 too. I would take the opportunity to Buy before the quarterly results, while the expectations are low (because there is no structural damage here yet).

My Buy call is comforted by valuations that are much more conducive and often absorbs bad news, especially if temporary. I have argued before how the valuations can absorb short-term earnings shocks at current levels and still look reasonable if the long-term thesis holds.

In Q4, alongside an expected worse charge-off, I see adjusted net income coming out well over the guided $137-$142m range. This is because the current run rate, even with deep moderation (say 25%), shows an adjusted net income above the upper end of the full-year guidance (~$142.5m). That could compensate for any negative sentiment.

The primary risk to the Buy thesis is if credit normalization does not stabilize as expected, although nothing negative is indicated yet. A sharper deterioration in borrower metrics, particularly if newer vintages show sustained weakness beyond seasonal patterns, could push charge-offs above manageable bands and pressure earnings despite pricing flexibility. Investors should also watch whether competitive intensity or regulatory developments limit OppFi’s ability to fully reprice risk. If loss trends accelerate, the earnings durability narrative would weaken, and the multiple may remain compressed longer than anticipated.

In summary, the thesis rests on three pillars – accelerating operating momentum, materially improved valuation, and credit costs that remain controlled (even if it stays at current levels). I maintain a Buy as long as charge-offs and provisions stay within historically manageable ranges and earnings power remains intact. I would reassess this position if net charge-offs move sustainably above 40% of revenue without offsetting pricing power, or if guidance turns structurally lower due to credit stress rather than seasonality.

data.title: This Bull Market And Nvidia Have Run Out Of Steam; Bear Market Ahead?
data.description:
I believe the stock market is at a critical juncture right now. Part of this is because many major market indexes have been stuck in a trading range and seem to have hit stall speed for the past few months. I see so much uncertainty in various areas now, which I think is making it hard for the stock market to break out of its recent trading range. Like most investors, I see reasons to be both bullish and bearish.

However, if the market is unable to resume climbing a "wall of worry" soon, I think the chances of a market plunge will become more likely. I think many market participants hoped that a strong earnings report from Nvidia (NVDA) would reignite the bull market, but the stock's post-earnings price action seems to be a potential warning sign for the market overall. This downbeat reaction seems to cap the results of the earnings season overall—despite strong earnings reports in general, the stock market has been unable to rally on this good news. With all this in mind, let's take a closer look at what could get the stock market back on track:

The Charts

As the chart below shows, the S&P 500 Index (SPY) has been stuck in a trading range for a few months now. While this index is still trading near record levels and near the 50-day moving average, I believe it risks a correction, as it appears to have run out of steam. If there is a drawdown, it might not be too bad, as it could find support near the 200-day moving average, indicated by the red trend line on the chart. A pullback to this level would represent a decline of about 7%.

The S&P 500 Index has held up relatively well because it is a broader index with a significant number of stocks outside the tech sector. Many investors are rotating out of tech stocks due to fears about an AI bubble, overspending on capex, and AI disruption in software and other sectors, and this has helped to support this broader index. As shown in the chart below, the NASDAQ 100 Index (NDX) appears to have formed a bearish double top on the chart since hitting record highs in October and then roughly matching those levels in January before pulling back to current levels. The failure to decisively break out to new highs in January is a potential warning sign for the bulls.

Earnings Season Has Failed As An Upside Catalyst

Many companies reported strong earnings overall, and earnings season is wrapping up now. The hyperscalers reported strong earnings results, but their stocks fell after they announced plans to increase capex spending. Nvidia was one of the last major tech stocks expected to report earnings. Nvidia reported very strong earnings, which was widely expected, but the post-earnings price action was negative, and that suggests that Nvidia can't carry the market higher for now. With earnings season largely over and the major market indexes still stuck in a trading range, the bulls will need to find new potential upside catalysts soon. If they don't, I believe the market is likely to resolve the position it has been stuck in by declining.

Here Are Some Potential Upside Catalysts That Bulls Can Focus On

Potential upside catalysts include lower interest rates as we move further into 2026 and potentially large tax refunds for many households. However, just as great earnings were expected and delivered by Nvidia, I think that investors may have already priced in the expectations for lower interest rates and larger tax refunds. This could mean these are non-events, just as Nvidia's strong earnings report was a non-event instead of a major upside catalyst for the bulls. So, it might take a combination of positives to get this bull market back on track, and it might also need more potential upside catalysts, which could include the following:

1) AI Disruption Fears Could Ease: The software sector has been one of the hardest hit by fears of AI disruption, but many sectors have been impacted by these fears recently. It is starting to look like these fears are getting out of hand. One potential example is a former karaoke company that recently announced it was changing its focus to AI and that it had a game-changing development in freight logistics using AI. When this announcement was made a few days ago, the market responded by wiping out over $17 billion in market cap in the freight sector.

I think this is a clear sign that investors are potentially overreacting, so if investors realize that the worst fears over AI disruption might not be very likely, the tech sector, software in particular, could be poised for a rebound. A rebound in software-related stocks like Microsoft (MSFT) could be the upside catalyst that this market needs for the bulls to take back control. If you look at the chart of the software sector below, you can see that these stocks recently reached the same lows hit during the stock market plunge after Liberation Day tariffs were announced in April 2025. This suggests that this sector may have bottomed out and could be poised for a relief rally, which could benefit the stock market overall.

2) IPO Success: OpenAI and Anthropic are two of the most revered AI startups, and both plan to go public in 2026. If these companies and other high-profile tech companies have successful IPOs, it could alleviate concerns about funding and circular deals that have created fears of an AI bubble. OpenAI in particular seems controversial because its major commitments will require massive funding. However, if they raise more cash in an IPO with an estimated $1 trillion market cap, investors will probably take their spending commitments more seriously.

3) Investors Could Rotate Back Into The Mag 7: One way to get this bull market back on track is if investors decide that the Mag 7 stocks are now undervalued after recent declines over capex spending plans. I think stocks like Amazon (AMZN) and Microsoft are deeply undervalued after plunging due to the announcement of increased capital expenditures. A recent Bank of America (BAC) investor survey suggests that an AI bubble is investors' biggest fear. However, many of the Mag 7 stocks are now trading far below market PE multiples.

By contrast, the recent rotation out of tech stocks and into consumer staples has pushed those valuations to levels that make no sense to me, unless this signals an approaching recession. This is especially true when considering the growth rates. For example, Walmart (WMT) now trades for about 43 times earnings, and earnings are expected to grow by around 10%. By contrast, Microsoft is now trading for just about half the multiple of Walmart, which is just around 23 times earnings, and it is expected to post higher growth rates for years to come.

As this Seeking Alpha article points out, consumer staple stocks are now more expensive than mega-cap tech stocks. If a bubble exists, it might be in consumer staple stocks, not the tech sector. Mega-cap tech stocks could regain favor soon because their valuations appear attractive, and this sector may have bottomed out. As shown below, the chart of the Roundhill Bug Tech ETF (MAGS) recently touched the 200-day moving average, and it has rebounded slightly from that level. This could signal that these tech stocks are poised to rebound.

4) Geopolitical Tensions: There are several global hotspots, and tensions between the United States and Iran appear to be growing. If diplomacy succeeds, or if any potential military action in the Middle East is short-lived, the stock market could be poised for a relief rally. I plan to use any stock market weakness stemming from geopolitical tensions as a buying opportunity.

5) Seasonal Trends: February is not historically known as a strong month for the stock market. By contrast, March and April are typically two of the best months for stocks. Perhaps this seasonal pattern will play out and get the bull market back on track with new potential highs in the coming weeks. During March and April, we might see the impact of bigger tax refunds, which could also support the bull case. Some analysts believe that many consumers might invest their tax refunds into the stock market, and this could be another upcoming positive.

Downside Risks Could Lead To A Bear Market

Stock market valuations are high and possibly priced for perfection. Margin debt is near record high levels, which has often set the stage for a bear market. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon recently warned about private credit, AI euphoria, and potential loan losses in the financial sector. The job market has been showing weakness for the past few months, and AI-related job losses could be poised to increase as time goes by.

These are just some of the many warning signs that could threaten the bull market and lead us into a bear market. When we see very strong earnings from Nvidia, yet the stock drops, it is a troubling sign and could be one more indicator that the bull market has topped out. If the stock market can't rally on good news (such as a strong earnings season), the path of least resistance could be lower. We could continue to see consolidation for a bit longer, where the market seemingly stagnates, but I believe the longer this drags out, the more likely it will resolve to the downside.

In Summary

I think there is still a good chance that investors will pile back into mega-cap tech stocks due to better valuations after a recent selloff. The valuations of stocks like Microsoft and Amazon look attractive when compared to historical valuations or to companies like Walmart. Fears about AI disruption may have become overblown, and if these fears ease, the software sector could rebound and help get the bull market back on track.

If AI startups like OpenAI and Anthropic have strong IPOs, this could renew investor interest in tech stocks and quell fears about an AI bubble. While there is still probably some time for the bulls to reassert control of this market, I think time is running out, especially since Nvidia's earnings results seem to have failed as an upside catalyst. I believe this is a higher-risk moment for the market, and as such, I am keeping high levels of cash in my portfolio so that I am prepared for market pullbacks. At the same time, I can't pass up opportunities to buy stocks like Amazon and Microsoft when their valuations are much lower today than they were just weeks ago.

data.title: Avery Dennison's Performance Is Solid, But Shares Are Too Pricey For My Liking
data.description:
Several months ago, in June 2025, I decided to revisit my neutral assessment of Avery Dennison (AVY). At that time, I thought that perhaps the business might be worthy of an upgrade. This followed a plunge in the share price of 15.3% at a time when the S&P 500 was up 18.9%. At the end of the day, however, I decided against upgrading it. Revenue and profitability had slipped compared to what the company saw in 2024. And, I claimed, the business looked mostly fairly valued as opposed to undervalued. So instead of upgrading it, I reaffirmed it as a "Hold" candidate. For context, whenever I rate a company a "Hold," I am making the claim that the stock should perform more or less similarly to the broader market for the foreseeable future. Since that day, we have seen that transpire. Shares are up 12.4%, only narrowly outperforming the 11.5% increase that the market enjoyed.

From a purely fundamental standpoint, management has continued to capture revenue growth. But the bottom line for the business has been more complicated. While net profits and adjusted net profits have pulled back, cash flows are on the rise. The good news is that management is implementing additional cost-savings initiatives throughout 2026. As things stand, the company looks pretty much fairly valued on an absolute basis and might be a bit pricey relative to other firms that have similarities to it. Given this, I think that maintaining my "Hold" rating is the right choice here.

It’s too early for an upgrade

As of this writing, investors have data for the company extending through the entirety of 2025. Obviously, this means the final quarter of the year as well. For that time, the business actually did quite well. Revenue came in at $2.27 billion, which exceeded the $2.19 billion the business reported a year earlier. Based on the data provided, this expansion was driven in large part by the company’s Materials Group, which operates as a provider of label materials, graphics, and reflective materials. It also provides certain functional bonding materials like tapes.

Year over year, revenue for the business jumped 5.1%, from $1.47 billion to $1.55 billion. This is great to see in and of itself. However, the devil is in the details here. Most of the revenue increase was actually driven by foreign currency fluctuations. If we strip those out, we would get a rise of just 0.3%. And to make matters worse, actual organic growth was negative to the tune of 0.9%. There were certain areas of strength, most notably high-value categories like the Intelligent Labels offerings that jumped at a high single-digit rate. Graphics and reflectives were up at a low single-digit rate as well. But on the whole, while the company did see a rise in volume and favorable changes in product mix, lower prices that it had to pass on to consumers because of deflation ultimately pushed organic results lower.

We also have the Solutions Group segment, which focuses on providing information and branding solutions to customers. Specific examples here include data management and digital identification associated with branding and embellishment, in addition to those same services for things like pricing and retail media and productivity. One thing that the company prides itself on is its emphasis on providing ultra-high-frequency RFID solutions that are vital for the modern-day supply chain. Everything from the food and grocery space to general retail, to the apparel market, to even aspects of the industrial economy, benefits from these types of solutions.

Revenue here was up only slightly, inching up 1.5% from $713.7 million to $724.2 million. The good news was that all of this was organic in nature, with management chalking that up to sales in the Intelligent Labels category popping at a low single-digit rate, Embelex-related revenue up at a high single-digit rate, and Vestcom growing in excess of 10%. While the Intelligent Labels portion of the company is more well-known, these other two are lesser known by market participants. For context, Embelex focuses on providing certain apparel and retail branding solutions, including woven and printed garment labels, heat transfers and embellishments, hashtags and trims, and the like. Meanwhile, Vestcom specializes in store shelf communication and pricing systems like shelf tags and price labels, promotional signage, digital shelf labeling integration technologies, and more. Overall, I would say that these value-added offerings certainly are appealing, and they proved that, at a time when more commoditized offerings are suffering, the company has some growth potential.

Unfortunately, even though revenue for the business improved, profitability took a hit. Net income contracted from $174 million to $166.4 million. Even on an adjusted basis, we get a contraction from $191.4 million to $189.4 million. Management blamed this weakness on higher employee-related costs and, when it came to the Solutions Group segment, investments aimed at growth opportunities. The good news is that cash flow at least increased. Operating cash flow jumped from $351.2 million to $376.8 million. If we adjust for changes in working capital, we would get a rise from $257.9 million to $281 million. And finally, EBITDA for the business expanded from $358.1 million to $367 million.

The final quarter of the 2025 fiscal year was not a blip on the radar. In fact, even though revenue for the business has continued to grow in recent years, ever since 2024 came to an end, profitability has taken a hit. In the chart above, you can see precisely what I mean. The good news here is that management is working to correct these profit issues. For 2026, management has not provided any comprehensive financial guidance. They did provide some estimates for the first quarter, with reported sales growth estimated to be between 5% and 7%, while organic sales growth should be between 0% and 2%. Economic conditions remain problematic, but the company is targeting incremental cost savings resulting from restructuring actions of around $50 million for the year. Between that and the prospect of share buybacks, they expect earnings growth to occur this year as opposed to a contraction in earnings like what we saw last year.

Beyond this, we don't really know what to expect. In all likelihood, the company will return additional capital to shareholders. This follows about $570 million of share buybacks during 2025 and $290 million of dividends. But unless we see a significant improvement in profitability, the stock is not cheap enough to justify a bullish outlook. In the chart above, you can see how shares are valued using results from 2024 and 2025. On an absolute basis, this is certainly not a bad picture. However, when it comes to other companies that have similarities to it, namely those in the packaging industry, it's not exactly the most compelling prospect. In that same chart, you can see that three of the five firms that I compared it to are cheaper than it is on a price-to-earnings and on an EV-to-EBITDA basis. Meanwhile, four of them are cheaper when it comes to the price-to-operating-cash-flow approach.

Long term, there certainly is potential for the business. In fact, in the image below, you can see their estimate, measured by units, of the size of the Intelligent Labels market. Across all categories that the company already plays in, it estimates the unit opportunity to be around 350 billion a year. And this is just the addressable market. It does not include the total market size that is substantially greater. What's more, in addition to focusing on growth in its existing addressable markets, the company has a history of expanding into new ones. In fact, since 2021, the company has experienced an expansion in its total addressable market of about 20 billion units. And this is because of case expansion and more established apparel and general retail businesses.

The business has no intention of being a commoditized provider, though. It is specifically focused on what it calls high-value categories. Right now in the Materials Group segment, only 38% of sales fall under the high-value designation. But when it comes to the Solutions Group segment, that number is around 60%. For the business in its entirety, about 45% of sales come from high-value offerings, which represents a nice increase over the 33% seen back in 2019. Geographically, the company is also intensely interested in growing into emerging markets. About 39% of the revenue associated with the Materials Group segment comes from those areas. Management has not provided an estimate of how much of the revenue coming from the Solutions Group segment is attributable to emerging markets. But we do know that the overwhelming majority of sales come from developed markets like the United States and Canada, as well as Europe. In total, about 30% of the firm's revenue comes from emerging markets, though. So there should be some growth prospects there. As expansion into high-value categories increases, you can expect profit margins to grow as well.

Takeaway

Based on the data provided, I would make the case that Avery Dennison remains an interesting prospect. But honestly, it's not one that I can get behind at this time. The company is decently priced, but it's nowhere near cheap enough to justify a bullish outlook. This is especially the case considering the recent profitability issues that management has relayed to investors. So for now, I think that maintaining it as a "Hold" candidate is the right move.

data.title: Acadia Healthcare: New Management Deserves A Shot At Turning Business Around
data.description:
Investment Overview

Acadia Healthcare Company, Inc. (ACHC) - a provider of behavioral healthcare services based in Franklin, Tennessee - shared its Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings results and business updates yesterday, and for once the market has reacted positively. Shares jumped in value from $16.5 to ~$21.5 yesterday and have held onto those gains today - current price is $21.6, and the market cap valuation is exactly $2bn.

Let's review the headline figures. Revenues in 2025 amounted to $3.3bn, at the higher end of (downgraded) guidance provided when announcing Q3 earnings; adjusted EBITDA came to $609m, and adjusted earnings per share ("EPS") to $2. The below table (shared in Acadia's earnings presentation) highlights revenues by service line:

Below is a reconciliation between GAAP and adjusted EBITDA also provided by Acadia, which is worth studying - for example, a net loss of $(1.18bn) in Q4 and $(1.1bn) was reported in 2025 as a whole, thanks primarily to a non-cash goodwill impairment charge.

In 2025, Acadia says it added 1,089 licensed beds during the year, including 311 to existing facilities and 778 beds from new facilities opened during the year. Acadia's CEO Debra Osteen told analysts on the company's earnings call yesterday:

Over the last several years, we have expanded our footprint to over 12,500 beds, taking care of 84,000 patients per day.

In terms of guidance for 2026, Acadia is expecting to generate revenues of $3.37bn -$3.45bn, adjusted EBITDA of $575m - $610m, adjusted earnings by diluted share of $1.3 $1.55, and to make capital expenditures of $255m - $280m.

Finally, Acadia reported a cash position of $133.2m with $595m available under its $1.0bn revolving credit facility and a net leverage ratio of 4x adjusted EBITDA. The long-term debt position was reported as $(2.47bn).

Analysis - New CEO Aims for Stability

In my last note on Acadia for Seeking Alpha, published after Q3 earnings in early November, I discussed how:

In late August 2024, Acadia stock traded >$80 per share - very close to its all-time high (shares traded ~$90 briefly in late 2022), but collapsed in value in September 2024 as the company disclosed that it had received a request for information and a jury subpoena from a U.S. Attorney and jury subpoena in two jurisdictions related to its admissions, length of stay and billing practices.

After the company shared annual earnings and 2025 guidance in February last year, its stock retreated further in value, to ~$30 per share, and traded at $20 per share when I published my last note.

Multiple headwinds were buffeting Acadia's business at that time - then CEO Chris Hunter told analysts that:

patient day growth fell short of expectations due to persistent softness in acute care Medicaid volumes and heightened payor scrutiny around authorizations. In addition, revenue was negatively impacted by elevated levels of bad debt and denials, which are expected to remain a headwind in the fourth quarter.

Insurers faced shrinking budgets due to higher patient healthcare utilization, coupled with the U.S. government's refusal to hike payment rates to ease the burden on the sector, heightened by the fact the government was in shutdown at the time Q3 earnings were released.

With a substantial amount of debt on its balance sheet and revenue growth negligible, perhaps the slide in Acadia's share price is understandable; however, I also noted in my last post that:

In September, it was reported that the activist investor Engine Capital, which had built up a ~3% stake in Acadia, had written to Acadia's Board of Directors, demanding changes to how the business was being run.

Engine outlined a series of issues it felt needed addressing by the management team and some strategy ideas to implement going forward, namely:

  • Strengthen the Board and Adhere to Best Corporate Governance Practices.
  • Align Executive Compensation to Shareholder Value Creation.
  • Immediately Halt All Growth Capital Investments.
  • Prioritize Improving Operations and Rationalize the Company’s Cost Structure.
  • Explore Asset Sales Across the Company’s Portfolio.
  • Repurchase Undervalued Shares..

I suggested this could be a catalyst for positive change at the company and also noted that "whether the CEO survives may be open to question." Nevertheless, I gave the stock a Buy rating, writing:

I am making Acadia a risky Buy opportunity. It is risky because a strategic turnaround of the business may need to be executed, and if it fails, shareholders may suffer substantial losses - and the entire business broken up. If it can succeed, however, the opportunities to enhance the value of a $1.9bn market cap business earning >$3.5bn revenues per annum are self-evident.

In January this year, it was reported that CEO Hunter would be leaving his role to be replaced by former CEO Debbie Osteen, a decision that was cheered by the market, with shares rising in value from ~$11.5 to >$15.

Yesterday during the earnings call, the new/old CEO told analysts:

The focus now is on delivering quality care for patients and consistent operational performance. We have the right mission, the right markets and the right foundation to deliver improved results. This work will take discipline and consistency. We remain focused on providing care with the highest standards for our patients and the communities we serve.

In response to one analyst's question re whether low- to mid-single-digit organic volume growth, low- to mid-single-digit pricing gains, and generating margin improvement were still possible, the CEO replied:

I do think the demand continues to be very strong. And I certainly don't see anything that would impact that either short term or long term.

Apparently, Engine Capital reduced its holding of Acadia stock on February 23rd, so its commitment to the long-term recovery of Acadia may be waning, but the return of an experienced CEO - a steady hand on the tiller at a time of crisis - is likely a net positive, in my view.

Looking Ahead - 2026 and Beyond

2026 does not look like being the year Acadia returns to growth and prosperity - its issues run too deep for such a fast turnaround. On its earnings call, the Chief Financial Officer - also relatively new to the role, as the previous CFO left their position last year, as did the Chief Operating Officer - said Acadia expected to add 400-600 beds in 2026:

primarily through the opening of new facilities nearing completion. This includes 3 facilities with joint venture partners, including new hospitals with Tufts Medicine, Methodist Health and Orlando Health.

The CFO also told analysts, "We anticipate full-year same-facility volume growth between 0% and 1%," reflecting 630 new beds added to the same-store bucket in Q1, offset by "an approximate 350 basis point headwind to the same-facility growth from changes in the New York Medicaid program."

The CFO said they expected a 2%-3% increase in same-facility revenue per patient day and outlined expectations to generate positive free cash flow "as we expect to see CapEx decline to a range of $255 million to $280 million."

The CFO also told analysts Acadia expected to earn between $820m and $830m of revenues in Q1, with adjusted EBITDA of $130m to $137m. Meanwhile, the CEO told analysts,

I think that we would only consider closing beds if there's no clear path to viability. And our focus right now is really on operating and improving the existing portfolio. So we're not talking about closures at this point and don't anticipate being in that situation.

As shown above, EPS is expected to decline in 2026, which arguably highlights the fact that 2026 is going to be a difficult reset year, with the new management team looking to correct mistakes made by the former management team.

Nevertheless, at this point in Acadia's evolution, arguably the numbers - in terms of revenues and earnings, at least, are less important than the fact that the market is reacting positively to changes in strategy. It's not always normal for a business's stock to leap in value when expectations for the coming year are set so low. As the CFO put it yesterday:

right now, we're focused on delivering in '26, ramping the new facilities we put in the ground and then being very disciplined on CapEx in the years after that as we get back to generating free cash and really showing off the cash-generating power the underlying business has now that we have these beds available and as we fill them.

Concluding Analysis: Am I Upholding My Buy Rating On Stock For 2026?

It's a difficult question to answer. Acadia stock is now up >50% year-to-date and ~8% since my last Buy call, which is a positive, perhaps reflecting what is known in the sports world as a "new manager bounce." But can it last?

There are few signs currently that the health insurance industry and government are aligned on policy or payment rates - seemingly, the government wants to pay less, while the sector demands more help - and that is a headwind that could lead Acadia to have to downgrade guidance or miss, e.g., Q1 guidance, which could reverse the goodwill Wall Street is currently showing the company.

Nevertheless, Acadia is a >$3bn revenue per annum company that generated >$270m of GAAP net income in 2022 and >$250m in 2024, owns a large portfolio of properties, and is capable of generating significant cash flow. As mentioned, as recently as August 2024, stock traded >$80 per share, a premium of >250%.

Often, contrarian trades look very attractive by certain metrics - price to sales and price to adjusted EBITDA in Acadia's case, plus former share price highs, but can backfire spectacularly; businesses do not typically resolve deep-seated structural issues overnight.

In summary, then, I am torn; however, I am opting to uphold my Buy rating because managing behavioral health issues is a massive industry, and therefore, a good management team (with a proven track record) will always stand a good chance of making a business like Acadia work, in my view.

It is clearly not an easy business to be in, and Acadia has suffered some significant reputational damage, being subject to investigations by the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission (source: behavioral health business) and having settled a securities fraud lawsuit by agreeing to pay $179m in November last year.

I would preach extreme caution, however - last April, I identified agilon health (AGL) as a potentially strong contrarian trade opportunity in the healthcare space, and shares are down 89% since that note at the time of writing.

As discussed, structural issues faced by distressed businesses often prove too deep-seated to fix, but in Acadia's case, for the time being at least, I feel as though the new CEO deserves time to implement new plans and potentially drag Acadia's business out of the doldrums.

data.title: AAII Sentiment Survey: Pessimism Rises
data.description:
Pessimism among individual investors about the short-term outlook for stocks increased in the latest AAII Sentiment Survey. Meanwhile, optimism and neutral sentiment decreased.

Bullish sentiment, expectations that stock prices will rise over the next six months, decreased 1.3 percentage points to 33.2%. Bullish sentiment is below its historical average of 37.5% for the second time in 13 weeks.

Neutral sentiment, expectations that stock prices will stay essentially unchanged over the next six months, decreased 1.5 percentage points to 27.0%. Neutral sentiment is below its historical average of 31.5% for the 84th time in 86 weeks.

Bearish sentiment, expectations that stock prices will fall over the next six months, increased 2.8 percentage points to 39.8%. Bearish sentiment is above its historical average of 31.0% for the sixth time in 13 weeks.

The bull-bear spread (bullish minus bearish sentiment) decreased 4.1 percentage points to –6.6%. The bull-bear spread is below its historical average of 6.5% for the third time in 13 weeks.

This week’s special question asked AAII members how they would describe the earnings guidance given by companies during fourth-quarter 2025 earnings season.

Here is how they responded:

  • Better than I expected: 27.2%
  • Approximately what I expected: 43.5%
  • Worse than I expected: 7.6%
  • Not sure/no opinion: 21.2%

This week’s Sentiment Survey results:

  • Bullish: 33.2%, down 1.3 percentage points
  • Neutral: 27.0%, down 1.5 percentage points
  • Bearish: 39.8%, up 2.8 percentage points

Historical averages:

  • Bullish: 37.5%
  • Neutral: 31.5%
  • Bearish: 31.0%

The AAII Sentiment Survey has been conducted weekly since July 1987. The survey and its results are available online.

If you want to become an effective manager of your own assets and achieve your financial goals, consider a risk-free 30-day Trial AAII Membership.

data.title: Carpenter Technology Gains Pricing Power In A Tight Market (Upgrade)
data.description:
Carpenter Technology Corporation (CRS) is experiencing durable market dynamics as a result of the tight supply of the nickel-based superalloy market, driven by increasing demand within the aerospace & defense industry. With limited suppliers and volumes produced, CRS has experienced substantial pricing power for its hardened alloys, driving up the average price per pound as volume sales increase. With a strong economic outlook for aircraft manufacturing and aftermarket services, I am upgrading my rating to a "Strong Buy" with a price target of $487/share at 21.15x eFY28 EV/EBITDA. I previously rated it a "Buy" in March 2025.

Carpenter Technology Corporation Operational Update

CRS experienced another quarter of sequential margin expansion, ending Q2’26 with an operating margin of 21.32%, up 42bps sequentially. Specialty Alloys operations (SAO) drove the incremental improvement to margins, expanding by 51bps sequentially and 385bps when compared to the previous year’s quarter. Though management provided some commentary regarding upward momentum for margins and the possibility of future quarters experiencing flat to down changes, guidance provided suggested the next two quarters will experience incremental improvements to close out eFY26 with four quarters of margin growth.

Growth in Q2’26 was driven by increased selling volumes and year-over-year price increases in SAO; Performance Engineered Products (PEP) experienced flat year-over-year volumes and a 13% decline in selling price.

Leading growth was the commercial aerospace subsector, with bookings increasing by 23% sequentially, underpinned by three long-term agreements secured with aerospace customers with “significant price increases.” In answering an analyst’s question, Tony Thene, CEO & Chairman of the Board of CRS, indicated that:

“These are substantial price increases going forward.”

Orders were largely driven by growth in engine materials, a market that is presently experiencing strong demand in both new builds and aftermarket services.

Offsetting orders in the aerospace & defense market segment was a decline in defense orders resulting from the government shutdown. Despite the quarter’s headwinds, management indicated that government orders have normalized since the shutdown, providing a more stable outlook for e2h26.

Looking ahead, CRS is well positioned to experience substantial growth through a robust aerospace market. According to an IATA report, the current aircraft shortage isn’t expected to normalize before 2031-2034, creating a substantial opportunity for both new builds and aftermarket engines. The report by IATA indicated that there is currently a deficit of 5,284 aircraft deliveries, suggesting that there’s pent-up demand for new jets that may drive increased aircraft yields. Airbus is expecting to deliver 870 jets in 2026, up from 793 in 2025. As for Boeing (BA), 737 production increased to 42 aircraft per month and 787 to 8 aircraft per month in Q4’25; Boeing’s backlog currently sits at 6,100 aircraft. In addition to this, engine maker Pratt & Whitney is supporting both the new build and aftermarket engine market, a balancing act that may provide tailwinds for CRS if capacity expands as a result of the manufacturing constraints.

Aftermarket can be an appealing market for growth given the aging fleet, as new aircraft manufacturing may fall short for replacement. Aircraft maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) companies StandardAero (SARO) and AAR Corp. (AIR) have each suggested heightened demand for engine and airframe services, supporting a growing market for CRS.

Carpenter Technology Corporation Financial Forecast

Looking ahead, capital spending for e2H26 is expected to increase relative to 1H26 as a result of CRS’s brownfield capacity expansion project, including a new vacuum induction melt furnace to increase production yields of its nickel-based superalloy. Accordingly, management is expecting to add 9,000 additional tons of production through this expansion. As a result, I’m expecting CRS to have an eFY26 capital spend of $311 million, just under half of which is associated with growth projects.

Despite the increase in capacity, management is expecting the nickel-based superalloy market to remain tight as a result of the increasing demand by aerospace & defense (including space) markets.

CRS improved the balance sheet in Q2’26 by refinancing its long-term debt, extending the maturity date to 2034 while reducing the interest rate to 5.625%. CRS also amended its revolving credit facility, expanding from $350 to $500 million. CRS closed Q2’26 with $232 million in cash & equivalents and $690 million in debt on the balance sheet for a leverage ratio of 0.62x net debt/EBITDA. In total, CRS had $730.8 million in liquidity, providing substantial financial flexibility to continue to reinvest in operations through the durable growth cycle.

Looking ahead to eQ3’26, I’m forecasting CRS to generate $728 million in net revenue with a diluted EPS of $2.62/share. My forecast assumes continued increases in deliveries paired with pricing power for CRS’s nickel-based super alloy, driving margin-accretive growth and enhancing operating leverage going forward.

Risks Related to Carpenter Technology Corporation

Bull Case

Tight market supply may continue to drive pricing power for CRS as volume production increases. Improved pricing can potentially drive substantial operating leverage, leading to margin-accretive growth over the coming years. With strong demand in the aerospace & defense market for MRO & new aircraft manufacturing, CRS’s market should remain durable through at least the next decade.

Bear Case

Tight supply could lead to peers increasing production and can potentially pressure pricing if overbuilding occurs.

Valuation & Shareholder Value

CRS shares are currently trading at a rich premium near historical highs at 27.48x EV/EBITDA. Despite the high trading premium, share valuations should normalize over time as operations catch up to the valuation premium as a result of the robust aerospace & defense market dynamics. Fundamentally, I believe shares should be valued at $487/share at 21.15x eFY28 EV/EBITDA; I am upgrading my rating to a "Strong Buy."

Using the model: the valuation table above references my financial forecast in the firm’s “financial position” section and ties it to the stock’s historical trading premiums. The trading premium array is derived through the normal operating cycle, with the blue-sky scenario being the stock’s peak multiple and the gray-sky scenario being the lowest point. The target multiple aims for the midpoint, or the most likely trading range for the company’s stock. The trading multiples from there are set to a probability factor based on the likelihood of the stock trading at that premium based on its historical presence. From there, the trading multiple is tied to the probability factor to derive its relative market capitalization and relative multiple.

data.title: MLPI: A New High‑Yield, Tax‑Friendly Energy ETF With Monthly Payouts
data.description:
Intro

While searching for ETFs with high yields and as little correlation to the S&P 500 (SP500) as possible, I came across the NEOS MLP & Energy Infrastructure High Income ETF (MLPI). This fund, part of the NEOS funds family, is a brand‑new issue launched just a couple of months ago in December.

When I first looked at it, it didn’t quite add up: the fund’s name points to High Income, yet the SA page shows a TTM yield of only 3.6% at the time of writing. Curious about this discrepancy, I found that since the fund has been around for just a couple of months and has only a few payouts so far, several characteristics simply need more time to reflect its real profile. According to the fund’s homepage, the actual distribution yield is 15.67%. That’s a more attractive figure and aligns much better with the fund’s name:

So, it appears the fund offers an attractive monthly distribution yield along with energy‑sector exposure. This combination potentially means lower correlation with the major equity indexes. I think it’s a great mix and worth taking a closer look at what’s behind the name.

Why MLPI?

Fund’s own positioning—why it claims a place in an investor’s portfolio:

Where might MLPI fit into an investment portfolio? MLPI may serve as a differentiated income alternative, seeking to unlock the tax efficiencies of MLP and energy infrastructure while aiming to offer high monthly income and the potential for equity appreciation. The strategy may also offer income with return characteristics that are potentially less correlated to traditional equity and fixed income allocations.

The targeted benefits of MLPI’s strategy in more detail:

  • High monthly income—generated through investments in MLPs and energy‑infrastructure companies, complemented by a data‑driven call‑option overlay designed to enhance distributable cash flow.
  • Tax‑efficient structure—the fund seeks to benefit from tax‑loss harvesting, pass‑through tax treatment, potential return‑of‑capital classification, and tax deferral driven by depreciation within energy‑infrastructure assets.
  • Equity appreciation potential—exposure to underlying MLPs and energy‑infrastructure companies provides room for capital growth alongside income.

The management fee is 0.68%.

Fund Holdings as of 02/26/2026:

The Williams Companies, Inc. (WMB) 10.62%
Enbridge Inc. (ENB) 9.68%
TC Energy Corp. (TRP) 7.75%
Kinder Morgan, Inc. (KMI) 7.05%
ONEOK, Inc. (OKE) 5.52%
Targa Resources Corp. (TRGP) 5.18%
Cheniere Energy, Inc. (LNG) 4.95%
Pembina Pipeline Corp. (PBA) 4.63%
Energy Transfer LP (ET) 4.41%
DT Midstream, Inc. (DTM) 4.41%

The fund holds a total of 24 companies in the oil and energy sector.

In addition, the fund writes call options against the Alerian MLP ETF (AMLP), as seen in their full holdings list. Surprisingly, the call-writing exposure, 1.72%, is quite small:

Security Name Shares Price Market Value Weightings
AMLP 03/20/2026 50 C -18,465 $1.66 $-3,065,190.00 -0.98%
AMLP 03/20/2026 50.5 C -18,465 $1.25 $-2,308,125.00 -0.74%

Portfolio Build-Up Strategy

Principal Investment Strategies of the Fund

The Fund is an actively-managed exchange-traded fund (“ETF”) that seeks to achieve its investment objective by (i) investing in a portfolio of energy infrastructure master limited partnerships (“MLPs”) and energy infrastructure companies that make up the MerQube North America MLP & Energy Infrastructure Index (the “MLP & Energy Infrastructure Index” or “Reference Index”); and (ii) utilizing a call options strategy to provide high monthly income, which primarily consists of writing (selling) call options on one or more ETFs that invest principally in energy infrastructure MLPs (“MLP ETFs”). The Fund seeks appreciation in the energy infrastructure sector through its investments in the constituents of the MLP & Energy Infrastructure Index. The Fund seeks to generate high monthly income from the premiums earned from the call options on the MLP ETFs.

A further description of how the fund allocates its capital:

Under normal circumstances, the Fund invests at least 80% of its net assets, plus borrowings for investment purposes, in securities of energy infrastructure MLPs and energy infrastructure companies, which the Fund defines as those companies included in the MLP & Energy Infrastructure Index.

MLPX (Global X MLP & Energy Infrastructure ETF) seems to track the same index, as its holdings match very closely:

Summary of Option Strategy

The fund writes one-month call options on an MLP ETF to generate current income, effectively trading potential upside for immediate yield. While the fund benefits from index growth, its gains are somewhat capped, as losses on the call positions will limit overall returns.

While the overall strategy description seems compelling, there is a notable weak point to consider, as I see it. As mentioned earlier, the fund currently writes only a small amount of call options against the AMLP ETF. The additional issue arises in my view because the holdings of MLPI and AMLP are not identical.

Here is the breakdown of the AMLP holdings for comparison:

AMLP’s top three holdings—Energy Transfer (ET), Plains All American Pipeline (PAA), and Western Midstream (WES)—together account for nearly 40% of the ETF. In contrast, WES is not included in the MLPI index at all, and ET, PAA, and Plains GP Holdings (PAGP) represent only about 8.5% of MLPI. This means MLPI is selling options on an ETF whose underlying assets make up only a minority of its own portfolio.

Because MLPs are generally less sensitive to direct oil and gas price movements and can be viewed as lower‑volatility, risk‑reducing infrastructure assets, the setup looks weak to me: the fund is writing options on the least volatile and most defensive part of its holdings—and one that carries limited weight in the overall portfolio.

While the underlying asset selection appears to follow index rules as outlined in the fund’s prospectus, the option‑writing framework is described only as call writing on an “MLP ETF.” This implies the fund may have some flexibility in choosing which ETF to use as the option‑writing base.

From my standpoint, it would arguably make more sense to write options, for example, on the MLPX ETF, which is based on the same index, is more volatile, and could generate higher option premiums.

Taxation

As the fund claims in its prospectus, it aims to be tax-efficient:

Here are some additional explanations from their prospectus:

Each year, you will receive an annual statement (Form 1099) of your account activity to assist you in completing your federal, state and local tax returns.

Fund distributions are generally taxable as ordinary income, qualified dividend income, or capital gains (or a combination), unless your investment is in an individual retirement account (“IRA”) or other tax-advantaged account. Distributions on investments made through tax-deferred arrangements may be taxed later upon withdrawal of assets from those accounts. The Fund seeks tax efficient returns by utilizing index options that receive favorable tax treatment under Internal Revenue Code rules because they qualify as “Section 1256 Contracts.” Under these rules, each section 1256 contract held by the Fund at year end is treated as if it were sold at fair market value on the last business day of the tax year. If the Section 1256 contracts produce capital gain or loss, gains or losses on the Section 1256 contracts open at the end of the year, or terminated during the year, are treated as 60% long term and 40% short term, regardless of how long the contracts were held.

An example of MLPI's monthly distribution taxation summary from their homepage:

In connection with the monthly dividend payment of $0.6739 per share payable on February 20th, 2026 to shareholders of record on February 18th, 2026, it is anticipated that 86% of such dividend will be a return of capital.

The fund’s risks, as highlighted in its prospectus, can be found here.

Takeaway

In conclusion, I find MLPI to be an interesting new choice for investors seeking high yield and diversification. While its holdings closely match the MLPX ETF, the primary attractions here are the options strategy, high distribution yield with monthly payouts, and tax efficiency. However, as noted earlier, the current execution of the option-writing strategy remains questionable to me.

I'm not a fan of actively managed funds, but MLPI seems to offer a hybrid approach—it is index-based at its core, while the option writing depends on the portfolio managers' decisions.

I am giving the fund a positive rating, but I believe it is better to start with a small position and monitor its performance over time, especially compared to AMLP and MLPX.

data.title: Blackstone Secured Lending: Why I Am Buying The SaaS Crash
data.description:
Blackstone Secured Lending (BXSL) has proven its value over time to BDC investors with consistent asset quality and strong NII coverage, but the investment firm could not resist the downward pull in the market lately. Now, with fears about SaaS loan exposure and potential write-down risk gripping investors, shares of BXSL are trading at a relatively large discount to NAV, given the BDC's historical context.

Blackstone Secured Lending managed to support its dividend with net investment income in the fourth quarter and maintained decent balance sheet quality, despite an increase in non-accruals. BXSL's valuation now also reflects a high safety margin for investors concerned about both lower benchmark interest rates as well as software exposure. While there are pros and cons to every investment, I believe the positives outweigh the negatives here, and I recommend investors to buy the SaaS panic.

Previous rating

Blackstone Secured Lending was a strong buy for me in my last article – Underpriced 11% Yield – mainly because of the company’s exceptional non-accrual profile that indicated high asset quality and strong NII performance even in a market that is seeing growing debt yield pressures. While I acknowledge that the risk of a dividend cut even for Blackstone Secured Lending has increased lately, I maintain a strong buy rating on BXSL based on the fact that the BDC is oversold and undervalued.

Well-performing private credit platform with excess coverage

The Q4 2025 earnings scorecard of Blackstone Secured Lending was defined by a Y/Y drop-off in net investment income, which is the key figure that investors pay attention to in order to calculate dividend payout ratios. Blackstone Secured Lending saw $0.80 per share in net investment income, which was $0.02 better than expected, but the BDC's income nonetheless dropped 4.8% year-over-year due to falling interest income. In Q4 2025, BXSL generated $327M in interest income, showing a drop-off rate of 1.8%, while its operating expenses increased 1.2% Y/Y.

BXSL’s excess dividend coverage – the amount of NII exceeding the firm’s dividend of $0.77 per share – shrank quarter-over-quarter to just $0.03 per share in Q4 2025, but the dividend nonetheless remained fully covered. BXSL consistently out-earned its dividend with NII in the last year, but the BDC is nonetheless vulnerable to a contraction in base rates in 2026.

BXSL

Q4 2024

Q1 2025

Q2 2025

Q3 2025

Coverage Trend

109.1%

-4.8%

Source: Author

Blackstone Secured Lending is a first lien-oriented investment platform with overall strong asset performance that provides a cushion against a dividend reset. I currently expect two or more federal fund rate cuts in 2026, which could pressure the company’s shrinking excess dividend margin, especially if the BDC's portfolio value were to shrink as well.

While the excess NII margin shrank in the fourth quarter, the trend in credit quality is slightly negative, but not so negative as to justify a change in stock rating. The BDC’s non-accrual percentage increased slightly Q/Q to 0.5%, up from 0.1%, but Blackstone Secured Lending is still one of the BDCs with the lowest non-performing loan ratios. Ares Capital (ARCC), Blue Owl Capital (OBDC), and Hercules Capital (HTGC) reported non-accrual ratios of 1.2%, 1.1%, and 0.1% in the last quarter, so comparatively, BXSL still ranks very highly here.

BXSL

Q4 2024

0.2%

150.0%

Source: Author's Compilation

SaaSpocalypse panic offers entry opportunity

In recent weeks, panic has gripped investors as some BDCs have high exposure to SaaS firms that may (or may not) be vulnerable to advancements in artificial intelligence. BDCs with heavy SaaS exposure have seen massive valuation declines as investors fear that AI-driven tech will make certain software products obsolete, thereby negatively affecting valuations of loans made to SaaS and software companies.

While this story may make for interesting headlines, there is no concrete evidence that AI is actually having a negative impact on the sector's overall loan performance. While BXSL has a high percentage of loans to the software sector, about 21%, the underlying credit and NII performance look solid enough to me to maintain a strong buy rating. For comparison, Ares Capital, Blue Owl Capital, and Hercules Capital have SaaS/software exposure percentages of 24%, 11%, and 35%.

High excess safety margin for BXSL

Even higher-quality BDCs have been rerated lower in recent months due to concerns about software exposure and related AI disruption risk, causing investors to sell into the weakness. The result: top BDC firms are now priced at a significant discount to their historical valuation averages.

Blackstone Secured Lending is trading at 0.9X net asset value, about 17% below the 3-year average P/NAV. Ares Capital, one of the most established private credit platforms in the market, is trading at a 3% discount to net asset value.

Blue Owl Capital – which faces a loss of trust following the failed merger with another private BDC in November 2025 – is trading at a 19% discount to net asset value. Despite merger-related issues, OBDC reported solid results for the fourth quarter, highlighting that investors may have overreacted to the current weakness in the market, as well as to the missed merger opportunity last year.

I see BXSL as a rock-solid BDC alternative for investors valuing quality and consistency. At the very least I would expect this BDC to reprice to net asset value, which as of the end of the December quarter was $26.92 per share, although the current BDC meltdown may negatively affect investor sentiment for longer.

Risks with BXSL

The biggest risk for BXSL, considering that the investment firm has seen a sequential drop-off in its dividend coverage, is obviously the risk of a dividend reset in a falling-rate world. While some BDCs have already lowered their dividends lately, such as FS KKR Capital (FSK) and Golub Capital BDC (GBDC), I believe that a dividend cut at this point for Blackstone Secured Lending is not a credible near-term risk.

Final thoughts

Blackstone Secured Lending remains a top BDC investment choice for income investors that want to hedge against a major downturn in the BDC market on SaaS fears: the BDC has managed to fully support its dividend in the last twelve months with net investment income, and the portfolio is overall, despite a sequential increase in the non-performing loan ratio in Q4 2025, performing well. In addition, BXSL outperforms other top BDCs such as Ares Capital and Blue Owl Capital in terms of asset quality.

I like that the SaaSpocalypse has made high-quality, first lien-focused private credit platforms a lot cheaper lately, and I am buying the drop in highly rated BDCs with excellent long-term performance records, such as ARCC, OBDC, and HTGC. The significantly reduced valuation multiplier also creates an excess safety margin for investors concerned about SaaS exposure and lower base interest rates in 2026.

data.title: Comex Silver Supplies Continue To Shrink Rapidly
data.description:
The CME Comex is the Exchange where futures are traded for gold, silver, and other commodities. The CME also allows futures buyers to turn their contracts into physical metal through delivery. You can find more detail on the CME here (e.g., vault types, major/minor months, delivery explanation, historical data, etc.).

The data below looks at contract delivery where the ownership of physical metal changes hands within CME vaults. It also shows data that details the movement of metal in and out of CME vaults. It is very possible that if there is a run on the dollar and a flight into gold, this is the data that will show early warning signs.

Gold

The chart below shows the spread between the spot price of gold and the futures contract pricing. As you can see, it blew out in 2025 (increasing contango). This created the massive arbitrage that resulted in gold traveling from London to New York. When the spread between futures and spot gets distorted, it suggests there is dislocation in the market. Spreads have never fully normalized after what happened last year.

As shown below, gold delivery volume for February matched what was seen in December. Despite being below the big months over the last year (Feb/Apr/Oct 2025), the delivery volume was still very strong on an overall historical basis.

As mentioned, February last year was a massive delivery month. The biggest on record and greatly exceeding this past February. However, when looked at on a notional basis (dollar amount of metal being delivered), you can see in the chart below that this February actually came closer than the chart above suggests. Total delivery volume last year was $22B and this year it is $17B.

Net new contracts (contracts that open and settle for immediate delivery) was a driver earlier in the month but completely stalled out mid-month.

Perhaps the most important data point is the actual metal leaving Comex vaults. When metal is “delivered” it does not mean it’s leaving the Comex. It means that Registered ownership is moving from one party to another. When the metal leaves the vault, that is where things get interesting.

As shown, last year saw a major influx as the arbitrage trade took hold, but that metal has been flowing back out. In the latest month, Registered metal saw quite a large down move. This metal did not flow into Eligible, which stayed relatively flat. Instead, the metal left the vault entirely. This shows sustained physical demand for gold.

Looking ahead to the March delivery period (a minor month for gold), we see a contract that is hovering near the average but seeing some selling pressure with 2 days remaining.

With the massive surge in inventory, the open interest relative to physical stocks is actually lower. This shows how much metal was added to Comex vaults last year.

Bottom line, February saw continued strength in delivery volume, and a decent amount of metal left the vault entirely.

Silver

While the gold market is showing a futures price that is getting higher above the spot rate (which caused metal to move from London to New York), the silver market is experiencing the opposite problem, backwardation. The spot price is above the futures price. This is actually a bigger warning sign because it highlights the pressure being put on the physical spot market.

Market Signal: Backwardation often signals a strong immediate demand or a supply shortage in the current spot market. The market is willing to pay a premium for the asset now, as the shortage is typically expected to resolve over the long term.

While the gap has closed in recent weeks, it is still there by about 10 cents.

Silver delivery was down from January delivery numbers, but compared to history, it was still quite strong. January and February are both minor months in Silver.

Switching to notional values, and focusing on the month of February, produces the chart below. While most of this is price appreciation (less than 200 more contracts were delivered in Feb 2026 vs Feb 2025), it still shows a very strong appetite for physical metal. Almost $2B of silver was delivered in the minor month of February.

Similar to gold, net new contracts were a driver until stalling out mid-month.

Silver-eligible inventories are being removed from the vault at a pretty rapid clip.

Registered metal (metal available for delivery) is also seeing major outflows. Since September, there has been a massive drawdown in Registered supplies. This is further evidence of strain in the physical market. Investors are taking delivery and moving it out of the vault. If we fall below 50M ounces, then Comex physical supplies will start to be extremely strained. While Eligible still has decent supply, much of that metal is not available for delivery.

As we approach March delivery, the silver contract has remained near the average for open interest.

On a relative basis, the story is similar: in line with the average.

Conclusion

The gold market has certainly calmed down when compared to the activity earlier in 2025. That said, demand remains strong despite the all-time highs in price.

Silver is showing significant demand and metal is leaving the vault at a rapid clip. This is a market in backwardation, facing high demand, record prices, and metal leaving the vault. This is a perfect storm for silver. After the strong pullback in January, we have seen a lot of speculative money get flushed out. While there are still speculators in this market, there are also big buyers with a strong physical appetite. This is going to put a lot of pressure on the Comex in 2026.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Time To Sell Peak Nvidia (Rating Downgrade)
data.description:
NVIDIA Corporation’s (NVDA) Q4 '25 earnings were quite superb. Revenue was up 73% to $68.1 billion. Gross margins also expanded 200 basis points to 75% and did not indicate any pricing pressure. And operating expenses expanded at a lower rate (44.89%), which meant they were distributed over a much wider base. The company held $62.6 billion in cash on the balance sheet and converted 54.4% of its net income in the year to free cash flows ($65.56 billion).

However, the near-perfect financial profile and the 5% dip post-earnings indicate the stock is already priced for perfection.

I am downgrading my rating to Sell, as I think current multiples understate concentration risk and, against game theoretic odds, assume sustained hyperscaler demand and structurally elevated margins.

Concentration Risks: Higher Than It Looks

While CFO Colette Kress indicated that revenue is diversifying, the 10-K filing reveals that just two customers accounted for 36% of revenue in FY26.

Analyst expectations for 2026 CapEx across the top 5 cloud providers and hyperscalers who collectively account for a little over 50% of our data center revenue are up nearly $120 billion since the start of the year and approaching $700 billion – Nvidia CFO Colette Kress during Q4 earnings call.

This revenue is currently a capex for its customers and not an operating expense. My primary concern here is not the health of the hyperscalers but the sustainability of their spending. For this spending to be sustainable, these companies need to show a proportional increase in the free cash flow from AI services. If not, their shareholders will eventually force a capex pivot. Because Nvidia’s revenue is so concentrated, even a 10% reduction in capex across these five customers could account for a $10 billion ($215 billion x 50% x (100%-90%)) hit on Nvidia’s top line.

It is also unclear as to what portion of the diversified revenue is from startups that are funded by the hyperscalers. If the Big Five reduce their direct buying, it would be accompanied by a reduction in venture investments in the ecosystem. Because the tail of these smaller customers is tethered to the head of the hyperscalers, the concentration risk is higher than it looks on the income statement.

Compute is Revenue? Not Always

In this new world of AI, compute is revenues. Without compute, there's no way to generate tokens. Without tokens, there's no way to grow revenues. So in this new world of AI, compute equals revenues – Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang during Q4 earnings call.

This comment reminded me of an article published about scaling laws on Nvidia’s blog (which is excellent) last year.

The whole bullish argument then was—Nvidia is not scaling models; it is scaling thinking. It helps to look at both the diversions in the graph above.

Test-time scaling allows a model to think longer before answering. You might have noted this in the chatbots that have toggle switches to think longer. This, understandably, is supposed to consume several times more compute than the faster mode. Inference was supposed to be cheap, but test-time scaling made inference expensive again.

However, test-time scaling turned out to be optimal when done through parallel scaling strategies. This meant that they could be distributed across separate chips or data centers more easily than training loops. Why is this relevant? Because it makes test-time scaling a commodity workload. If Microsoft has to spend a dollar of compute on Nvidia H100s but they can achieve the same for 30 cents on their Maia chips, they have a fiduciary duty to switch. So while test-time scaling increases the total addressable market for compute, it could simultaneously undercut Nvidia’s pricing power within that market.

The post-training scaling also undercuts the comment about compute being too tied to revenues. Distillation is a post-training scaling method, and OpenAI (OPENAI) claimed DeepSeek (DEEPSEEK) used distillation to train their own models. If a $5 million distillation can replicate the reasoning capabilities of a $500 million training run, then the “Compute = Revenue” equation suffers from a huge deflation. So I remain very skeptical of this idea that you need to burn more silicon to get more value.

Valuation and Conclusion

Nvidia trades at ~$23x FY27 earnings estimates. That looks reasonable for a company growing at this pace. However, a lot of the incremental revenue is likely coming from the same concentrated set of customers for the next two years. Pressure in hyperscaler stocks indicates they are already pushing the limits on capital intensity. Not to mention the consensus revenue growth in the second year (FY28) is around 23%. So we had two years of triple-digit growth followed by two years of mid-60s percentage growth, which is expected to be followed by a much steeper descent.

A 23x multiple is cheap for a company exhibiting hypergrowth, but it is fair-to-expensive for a company entering a deceleration curve with a concentrated set of customers. Considering these factors, I think the risk-reward is skewed to the downside and downgrade my rating on the stock to Sell.
